course.subject: ENTR
course.name: Social Innovations and Entrepreneurship
course.description: Building a social enterprise can be markedly different from building a commercial one. When well deployed, social innovations can meet social needs that the government welfare, business corporations or charity-based social welfare cannot easily fulfill. A commercial entity should also be aware of the social impacts of its business decisions. This course introduces corporate social responsibility (CSR), social innovations, and the factors of consideration to start a social enterprise. This includes current topics on operation models, sustainability, team building, case studies, strategies, practices, etc. Site visits and student projects will be involved.

reviews.author: Marin
reviews.comment_content: The stuff taught was simple and listening to what's going on is enough to understand everything. We looked at some social enterprises that we visited to understand how they operate and function, but didn't go into any very specifically.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor didn't really teach much, he just gave some insight and commented on what guests were saying mostly.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% individual project
40% group project
10% attendance
20% participation
reviews.comment_workload: Very little to do, apart from the projects that should take a few hours in total. You might be required to read a few things before class but that's it.
